title: What happens if I am sued for more money than I have and lose?
question: do I have to pay them every penny I have and it ends there? do I owe them money when I come across some? will I go to jail if I can't pay all of it?
answers:
No, you will not go to jail because of a civil judgment against you. However, as my other colleagues have pointed out, once a creditor obtains a judgment against you, they can proceed with a variety of collection remedies, including wage garnishment, bank levies, and liens against property.

You can explore the possibility of discharging this debt through bankruptcy. Provided you qualify for bankruptcy relief, and provided that the judgment is not for a "non-dischargeable" debt such as back child or spousal support, for a debt that arose through fraud of some kind, drunk driving, or a handful of other types of debt, then the debt should be dischargeable in bankruptcy.

My office offers free consultations to anyone in the Bay Area considering filing bankruptcy. We are generous with our time (an hour), and there is no obligation. We will look at whether you might qualify for Chapter 7 or Chapter 13, explain what these do and don't do, and give you our honest opinion as to whether or not bankruptcy might offer you effective debt relief.

The first video on my web site, linked below, covers all options when sued on a credit card debt, including the option of just doing nothing. Not everyone has the funds to settle a lawsuit, which is why there are many thousands of unpaid judgments. The plaintiff's attorney then will try to collect the unpaid judgment, but I have on Avvo a legal guide on how to reduce or eliminate a wage garnishment. Still, there are other ways that a debt collector can attempt to enforce an unpaid judgment, such as by levying the debtor's bank account or making the debtor appear in court to explain their finances to try to determine if there are any funds or assets to collect the judgment. Another bad part about an unpaid judgment is that interest accrues at 10% per year and they can be renewed every few years until satisfied, which means that you may want to try to nip it in the bud now, if possible.
